Introduction to AEKO Chain.title: Introduction to AEKO Chain
Introduction to AEKO Chain.html:
Introduction to AEKO

AEKO Chain is the first Layer-1 blockchain built specifically for the SocialFi era. It combines the high-performance execution of the Solana Virtual Machine (SVM) with a native Permission Layer to enable compliant, scalable, and identity-aware decentralized applications.

Performance

65,000+ TPS with sub-second finality using Sealevel parallelization.

Identity

Native Permission Layer with varying clearance levels (L0-L5) for Sybil resistance.

Why AEKO?

Traditional blockchains treat all users anonymously, which leads to bot spam and lack of accountability. AEKO introduces Proof of Humanity and Clearance Levels directly into the protocol, allowing developers to build apps that require specific user verifications without managing the infrastructure themselves.

Architecture Overview.title: Architecture Overview
Architecture Overview.html:
Architecture Overview

AEKO's architecture consists of three primary layers working in unison:

1. The Execution Layer (SVM)

A forked and optimized version of the Solana Virtual Machine. It handles transaction processing, smart contract execution, and state management. It utilizes Proof of History (PoH) for timekeeping and Sealevel for parallel transaction processing.

2. The Permission Layer

A set of native eBPF programs that intercept transactions before they reach the execution state. It validates user Clearance Levels (L0-L5) and enforces compliance rules defined by the network or specific dApps.

3. The Social Graph Layer

An indexed data layer that maps on-chain identities to social interactions. It uses Content Signatures to verify the authenticity of posts and interactions, feeding into the Reputation Protocol.

Wallet Setup.title: Wallet Setup
Wallet Setup.html:
Wallet Setup

To interact with AEKO Chain, you need a compatible wallet. While AEKO supports standard SPL wallets, we recommend the official AEKO CLI or partner wallets for full identity feature support.

CLI Wallet

# Install AEKO CLI
curl -fsSL https://release.aeko.chain/install | bash

# Generate a new keypair
aeko-keygen new --outfile ~/.config/aeko/id.json

# Set config to devnet
aeko config set --url https://api.devnet.aeko.chain

Browser Wallets

  • Phantom (AEKO Fork): Supports native L1 clearance display.
  • Backpack: Integrated xNFT support for SocialFi apps.

Identity & Clearance.title: Identity & Clearance Levels
Identity & Clearance.html:
Identity & Clearance Levels

AEKO replaces the standard 'anyone can interact' model with a tiered clearance system. This allows applications to gate access based on trust and verification.

LevelNameRequirementCapabilities
L0GuestNone (Public Key only)Read-only access, no transaction capability.
L1UserBasic Captcha / EmailBasic token transfers, low-value interactions.
L2VerifiedSocial Login / PhoneStandard dApp usage, posting content.
L3CitizenGov ID / KYCGovernance voting, running a validator node.

Gatekeeper Programs.title: Gatekeeper Programs
Gatekeeper Programs.html:
Gatekeeper Programs

Gatekeepers are specialized on-chain programs that verify user credentials and issue Clearance Levels. They act as the bridge between off-chain identity providers and on-chain permissions.

How it Works

  1. User Request: A user requests a clearance upgrade via a client app.
  2. Off-Chain Verification: The app verifies the user's identity (e.g., via OAuth or Civic).
  3. On-Chain Issue: The Gatekeeper program validates the proof and mints a Soulbound Token (SBT) to the user's wallet.
  4. Permission Check: Subsequent transactions check for this SBT to authorize actions.

Soulbound Tokens.title: Soulbound Tokens
Soulbound Tokens.html:
Soulbound Tokens (SBTs)

SBTs are non-transferable NFTs that represent a user's identity, reputation, or achievements. On AEKO, they are the technical implementation of Clearance Levels.

  • Non-Transferable
    Cannot be sent to another wallet, ensuring identity integrity.
  • Revocable
    Issuers can revoke SBTs if a user violates community guidelines or loses their clearance status.
  • Composable
    Smart contracts can query a user's SBT balance to instantly determine their eligibility for features.

Compliance Hooks.title: Compliance Hooks
Compliance Hooks.html:
Compliance Hooks

Compliance Hooks are pre-transaction checks that enforce regulatory or community rules. They run at the protocol level, ensuring that no transaction can bypass required checks.

Use Cases

  • KYC/AML Checks: Ensure sender and receiver are not on sanctions lists.
  • Spending Limits: Enforce daily transaction limits for lower clearance levels.
  • Content Moderation: Prevent interactions with flagged or banned content IDs.

Content Layer Storage.title: Content Layer Storage
Content Layer Storage.html:
Content Layer Storage

AEKO utilizes a hybrid storage model to handle the massive data requirements of SocialFi applications efficiently.

On-Chain (Hot)

Critical metadata, content hashes, and interaction pointers are stored directly in Solana account state for sub-second access.

Off-Chain (Cold)

Actual media files (images, videos) and long-form text are stored on decentralized networks like Arweave or IPFS, anchored by their hashes on AEKO.

Reputation Protocol.title: Reputation Protocol
Reputation Protocol.html:
Reputation Protocol

The Reputation Protocol aggregates a user's on-chain activity into a quantifiable score. This score influences visibility, governance weight, and platform rewards.

Scoring Factors

  • Clearance Level: Higher clearance provides a higher base score.
  • Engagement Quality: 'Likes' from high-reputation users weigh more than those from low-reputation users.
  • Tenure: Long-term active users gain a 'Time Multiplier'.

Proof of Engagement.title: Proof of Engagement
Proof of Engagement.html:
Proof of Engagement (PoE)

PoE is AEKO's mechanism for distributing rewards to active participants. Unlike 'Click-to-Earn', PoE focuses on meaningful interactions verified by the Social Graph.

Validators analyze the engagement graph at the end of each epoch. Users who contributed high-quality content (measured by the Reputation Protocol) receive a portion of the network's inflation rewards.

Content Signatures.title: Content Signatures
Content Signatures.html:
Content Signatures

Every piece of content on AEKO is cryptographically signed by the creator's private key. This ensures provenance and authenticity.

Benefits

  • Anti-Impersonation: Users can easily verify if a post is truly from a creator.
  • Copyright: On-chain proof of authorship for digital assets.
  • Censorship Resistance: Signed content cannot be altered by third parties, only hidden by frontend filters.

AEKO SVM Runtime.title: AEKO SVM Runtime
AEKO SVM Runtime.html:
AEKO SVM Runtime

The core of AEKO Chain is a highly optimized fork of the Solana Virtual Machine (SVM). It is designed to handle the high throughput required for social media scale.

Key Optimizations

  • Compute Budget: Increased compute units per block to allow for complex social graph traversals.
  • Account Indexing: Native indexing for social relationships (followers/following).
  • Fee Markets: Localized fee markets prevent one viral dApp from congesting the entire network.

Sealevel Parallelization.title: Sealevel Parallelization
Sealevel Parallelization.html:
Sealevel Parallelization

Unlike EVM chains that process transactions sequentially, AEKO uses Sealevel to process thousands of smart contracts in parallel.

Transactions describe all the states they will read or write during execution. This allows the runtime to find non-overlapping transactions and execute them concurrently, utilizing all available validator cores.

Consensus Mechanism.title: Consensus Mechanism
Consensus Mechanism.html:
Consensus Mechanism

AEKO uses Proof of History (PoH) combined with Tower BFT to achieve consensus.

Proof of History

A cryptographic clock that allows validators to agree on the passage of time without communicating. This reduces messaging overhead and enables sub-second block times.

Tower BFT

A PBFT-like consensus algorithm that leverages the PoH clock to reach finality quickly. Validators vote on forks, and votes have a lock-out period that increases exponentially.

Validator Guide.title: Validator Guide
Validator Guide.html:
Validator Guide

Help secure the AEKO network by running a validator node. Validators earn rewards for processing transactions and participating in consensus.

Requirements

  • CPU: 12+ cores / 24+ threads (AMD Ryzen 9 or Threadripper recommended).
  • RAM: 128GB+ DDR4/DDR5.
  • Storage: 2TB+ NVMe SSD (PCIe Gen4).
  • Clearance: L3 (Citizen) Identity Verification.

Rust SDK.title: Rust SDK
Rust SDK.html:
Rust SDK

The primary language for developing on AEKO is Rust. The AEKO SDK provides all the necessary tools to write, test, and deploy high-performance programs.

Example Program

use aeko_program::{
    account_info::AccountInfo,
    entrypoint,
    entrypoint::ProgramResult,
    pubkey::Pubkey,
};

entrypoint!(process_instruction);

fn process_instruction(
    program_id: &Pubkey,
    accounts: &[AccountInfo],
    instruction_data: &[u8],
) -> ProgramResult {
    // Your logic here
    Ok(())
}

Program Architecture.title: Program Architecture
Program Architecture.html:
Program Architecture

AEKO programs are stateless. All state is stored in separate 'Accounts' passed to the program during execution.

Key Components

  • Program ID: The public key of the executable account.
  • Instruction Data: A byte array containing the command and arguments.
  • Accounts: The data accounts the program will read from or write to.

Native Syscalls.title: Native Syscalls
Native Syscalls.html:
Native Syscalls

AEKO introduces specific syscalls for the Permission Layer that are not found in standard Solana.

  • sol_get_clearance_level(pubkey): Returns the L0-L5 clearance of a user.
  • sol_verify_content_signature(data, signature, pubkey): Verifies a content signature on-chain cheaply.

Security Best Practices.title: Security Best Practices
Security Best Practices.html:
Security Best Practices

Writing secure smart contracts is critical. Follow these guidelines to prevent exploits.

  • Check Signers: Always verify that critical accounts have signed the transaction.
  • Validate Owners: Ensure accounts are owned by the expected program.
  • Integer Overflow: Use checked_add and checked_sub for math operations.
  • PDA Validation: Always derive Program Derived Addresses on-chain to verify they are correct.

Governance.title: Governance
Governance.html:
Governance

AEKO utilizes a bicameral (two-house) governance system to balance economic interests with social integrity.

Token House vs Citizen House.title: Token House vs Citizen House
Token House vs Citizen House.html:
Token House vs Citizen House

To prevent plutocracy, AEKO splits governance into two houses:

Token House

Voting Power: 1 Token = 1 Vote.
Scope: Protocol upgrades, inflation rates, treasury allocation.
Goal: Economic security and growth.

Citizen House

Voting Power: 1 Citizen (L3+) = 1 Vote.
Scope: Public goods funding, code of conduct, clearance criteria.
Goal: Community alignment and fairness.

Proposal Lifecycle.title: Proposal Lifecycle
Proposal Lifecycle.html:
Proposal Lifecycle

How an idea becomes law on AEKO Chain.

  1. Discussion: Post the idea on the governance forum for feedback.
  2. Draft: Create a formal proposal with executable code or text.
  3. Submission: Submit to the relevant House (Token or Citizen).
  4. Voting: A 3-day voting period where delegates cast votes.
  5. Execution: If passed, the proposal is executed on-chain after a timelock.

Treasury Management.title: Treasury Management
Treasury Management.html:
Treasury Management

The AEKO Community Treasury holds 15% of the initial token supply and receives a portion of transaction fees.

Funds are used for:

  • Grants: Funding developers building on AEKO.
  • Liquidity: Providing liquidity to official AMM pools.
  • Operations: Marketing and legal expenses.

Staking.title: Staking
Staking.html:
Staking

Stake your AEKO to help secure the network and earn rewards.

How to Stake

  • Delegation: You can delegate your tokens to a Validator without giving up custody.
  • Lockup: Tokens are locked for an epoch (approx 2 days).
  • Rewards: Rewards are automatically compounded into your stake account.
